content:
No, voltage is not just the concentration of electrons. Voltage is a measure of the electric potential difference between two points in a circuit, which represents the amount of energy required to move a unit charge from one point to another. The concentration of electrons, on the other hand, is a measure of the number of electrons present in a given volume or area.

Voltage can exist in a circuit even if the concentration of electrons is constant. For example, a voltage difference can be created across a battery, even though the concentration of electrons inside the battery does not change. The voltage difference drives the flow of electrons from the negative terminal to the positive terminal of the battery, producing an electric current.
